content: 1. What does the price premium approach to measuring brand equity describe?

answers.text: a) The frequency of discount campaigns
b) The price consumers are willing to pay extra for a brand
c) The comparison of stock levels
d) The market share of competitors

content: 2. Which advantage is attributed to brands in the context of risk reduction?

answers.text: a) They increase price sensitivity
b) They foster irregular revenues
c) They stabilize cash flows through brand loyalty
d) They make investors more cautious

content: 3. What does the sales premium approach measure?

answers.text: a) The price elasticity of demand
b) The sales volume compared to unbranded products
c) The production effort
d) The number of brand licenses

content: 4. What does the sales premium approach to brand valuation refer to?

answers.text: a) Comparison of production costs between branded and no-name products
b) Measurement of higher sales of a brand compared to an unbranded product
c) Analysis of discount promotions in retail
d) Observation of competitors' market share

content: 5. Which brand strategy is particularly suitable for premium or luxury brands?

answers.text: a) Sales premium strategy
b) Price premium strategy
c) Discount strategy
d) Mass market strategy

content: 6. What is an advantage of a strong brand regarding business risk?

answers.text: a) Higher price sensitivity of consumers
b) Reduction of cash flow volatility
c) Less brand loyalty
d) Increased dependency on competition

content: 7. What is the Price Sensitivity Meter by Van Westendorp used for?

answers.text: a) To analyze retail price promotions
b) To determine the acceptable price range of a product
c) To calculate production costs of a product
d) To measure brand loyalty

content: 8. What are the two components of the Interbrand brand valuation model?

answers.text: a) Pricing strategy and revenue
b) Brand image and advertising budget
c) Brand performance and brand strength
d) Market share and awareness

content: 9. What is a key challenge in measuring brand value?

answers.text: a) Choosing the right brand name
b) Uncertainty regarding future developments
c) The number of available brands
d) The impossibility of evaluating brands internationally

content: 10. Which aspect is NOT a criterion in the Interbrand scoring model?

answers.text: a) Market leadership
b) International presence
c) Stability
d) Price elasticity

content: 11. Why do brand value estimates differ significantly between institutions?

answers.text: a) Because brands lack legal protection
b) Because different models use different valuation approaches
c) Because companies keep data confidential
d) Because brand values are purely speculative

content: 12. What does the combined price and sales premium approach measure?

answers.text: a) The profitability of individual sales channels
b) The total brand value through price and sales advantages
c) The number of discounted products sold
d) Brand awareness among children

content: 13. Why are brands considered key intangible assets of companies?

answers.text: a) They have a clear legal valuation
b) They can be valued independently of physical capital
c) They mainly affect production costs
d) Their value automatically decreases over time

content: 14. What does the 'Role of Brand Index' mean in the Interbrand model?

answers.text: a) The legal protectability of a brand
b) The share of brand value in total revenues
c) The advertising intensity for a product
d) The number of registered trademark rights

content: 15. Which statement applies to indicator-based brand valuation approaches?

answers.text: a) They ignore long-term brand effects
b) They are based on internal employee surveys
c) They use criteria such as market leadership and stability
d) They fully replace financial brand valuation
